channel.description:
there havent been any updater outputs recently, so i figured id post the output of a new updater i was writing which i have not worked on in a while[code] - Downloading runescape.jar.. - Loading classes.. - Finished loading 518 classes from runescape.jar! - Loading identifiers.. - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Login - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Applet - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Buffer - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Cipher - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Mouse - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Node - Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.PolylingualString - Finished loading 7 class identifiers! - Identifying classes and members.. - Finished identifying all classes and members! - Renaming identified members.. [ Login ] ^ Login = mm - Login.login(I)V = mm.e(I)V [ GameApplet ] ^ GameApplet = gv - GameApplet.error(Ljava/lang/String;Z)V = gv.a(Ljava/lang/String;Z)V - GameApplet.validHost(I)Z = gv.g(I)Z [ Buffer ] ^ Buffer = ae - Buffer.offset = ae.bb - Buffer.buff = ae.yb [ Cipher ] ^ Cipher = jv [ Mouse ] ^ Mouse = dk - Mouse.removeListeners(B)V = dk.e(B)V - Mouse.component = dk.U - Mouse.addListeners(ILjava/awt/Component;)V = dk.a(ILjava/awt/Component;)V - Mouse.posX = dk.P - Mouse.posY = dk.O - Mouse.storeEventAttr(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;B)V = dk.a(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;B)V - Mouse.reviseModifiers(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;I)I = dk.a(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;I)I [ Node ] ^ Node = cg - Node.unlink(Z)V = cg.a(Z)V [ PolylingualString ] ^ PolylingualString = wt - PolylingualString.getString(II)Ljava/lang/String; = wt.a(II)Ljava/lang/String; - Finished renaming all identified members! - Dumping classes.. - Finished dumping classes to runescape_out.jar! [/code]
instead of injecting hooks like most updaters do, it renames all identified fields in the client and updates all constant pool entries referencing the old names

item.description:
@Holic wrote:

[13:39:16] ARAB Updater [13:39:17] RuneScape build #582 [13:39:17] FileOnDisk: [13:39:17] de implements com.arab.bot.hooks.FileOnDisk [13:39:17] getFile() returns File de.a [13:39:17] getRandomAccessFile() returns RandomAccessFile de.d [13:39:17] Mobile: [13:39:17] bn implements com.arab.bot.hooks.Mobile [13:39:17] getMessage() returns String bn.Qb [13:39:17] getMovementSpeed() returns int bn.vc [13:39:17] Node: [13:39:17] cg implements com.arab.bot.hooks.Node [13:39:17] getPrev() returns cg cg.e [13:39:17] getID() returns long cg.i [13:39:17] getNext() returns cg cg.k [13:39:17] Stream: [13:39:17] ae implements com.arab.bot.hooks.Stream [13:39:17] getOffset() returns int ae.bb [13:39:17] getBuffer() returns byte[] ae.yb [13:39:17] Interface: [13:39:17] ts implements com.arab.bot.hooks.Interface [13:39:17] getChildren() returns ts[] ts.v
Started on a new updater.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:14, topic:328148”][quote author=BAsh link=topic=424530.msg3118507#msg3118507 date=1265276841]

I took a look at the renaming subsection within the factor application and it is specific to ZKM’s deobfuscation renamer; he iterates through all the UTF8 constant pool entries and revises if they are to be replaced with the updated name checking to see if it matches with the following regex string:

.*?(a" + needle + "(?!_Sub|\\d)(?:(?:Array)*|_)+\\d+).*? which references object names like ‘aClass[_Sub]’

what about anClass ?
[/quote]
what about preschool grammar?[/quote]
anIntegerArray then.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:17, topic:328148”]yes we all know about the bug - however it’s still trivial to fix[/quote]It wouldn’t be any problem using it as he did, since the way ZKM renames classes isn’t likely to be found in use anywhere in the client. Mine is just a more generic approach.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

yes we all know about the bug - however it’s still trivial to fix

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:14, topic:328148”]regardless, seeing as you’re stupid like me, you were completely oblivious to the RemappingClassAdapter and Remapper classes placed in org.objectweb.asm.util[/quote]I am not interested in learning how to use the ASM API since I am flooded with shit to do, and honestly do not feel a need to learn it anyways.

oksuper_:

regardless, abraham, we’re not shoving the patterns down you’re throat… we’re shoving an elegant solution down your throat; feel free to modify the patterns.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:328148”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=424530.msg3118450#msg3118450 date=1265260724]

pd wrote and released an open-source bytecode renamer that worked extremely well towards the end of the aryan days. I think he called it ‘factor’ and you can download it here:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/factor.tgz

As to whether updaters should rename, inject accessor methods, or anything else. I don’t really think they should do anything but output a map of fields to nice names. Then you can have as many programs as you want to parse that in and do whatever you want with it. But hey, to each their own I guess.
[/quote]I took a look at the renaming subsection within the factor application and it is specific to ZKM’s deobfuscation renamer; he iterates through all the UTF8 constant pool entries and revises if they are to be replaced with the updated name checking to see if it matches with the following regex string:

.*?(a" + needle + "(?!_Sub|\\d)(?:(?:Array)*|_)+\\d+).*? which references object names like ‘aClass[_Sub]’

As I said before, taking his approach would have been much more facile, but I preferred to take the more generic approach seeing as my updater does not (and hopefully, will not) use ZKM’s deobfuscator beforehand, and I’d rather not have it rely on an external application.

There are patterns in the first place so that they can be modified to suit your needs. You don’t have to use it, it is just nice to have another way to do it.[/quote]In one of my posts above, I stated that the reason as to why I do not simply iterate through all ‘utf8’ constants and revise if they contain the name of the class/field/method to be renamed using some sort of predefined regex pattern is because the strings may actually not be pointed to by a ‘name_and_type’ constant or by a class member reference and instead, they may simply be pointed to by a ‘string’ constant (in which case, the application most likely pushes it onto the stack in some function) and I obviously would not want to erroneously modify a valid string - an existent ‘bug’ in his renamer.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:9, topic:328148”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=424530.msg3118430#msg3118430 date=1265257980]
pd wrote and released an open-source bytecode renamer that worked extremely well towards the end of the aryan days. I think he called it ‘factor’ and you can download it here:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/factor.tgz

As to whether updaters should rename, inject accessor methods, or anything else. I don’t really think they should do anything but output a map of fields to nice names. Then you can have as many programs as you want to parse that in and do whatever you want with it. But hey, to each their own I guess.
[/quote]I took a look at the renaming subsection within the factor application and it is specific to ZKM’s deobfuscation renamer; he iterates through all the UTF8 constant pool entries and revises if they are to be replaced with the updated name checking to see if it matches with the following regex string:

.*?(a" + needle + "(?!_Sub|\\d)(?:(?:Array)*|_)+\\d+).*? which references object names like ‘aClass[_Sub]’

As I said before, taking his approach would have been much more facile, but I preferred to take the more generic approach seeing as my updater does not (and hopefully, will not) use ZKM’s deobfuscator beforehand, and I’d rather not have it rely on an external application.[/quote]

There are patterns in the first place so that they can be modified to suit your needs. You don’t have to use it, it is just nice to have another way to do it.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:13, topic:328148”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=424530.msg3118450#msg3118450 date=1265260724]
I took a look at the renaming subsection within the factor application and it is specific to ZKM’s deobfuscation renamer; he iterates through all the UTF8 constant pool entries and revises if they are to be replaced with the updated name checking to see if it matches with the following regex string:

.*?(a" + needle + "(?!_Sub|\\d)(?:(?:Array)*|_)+\\d+).*? which references object names like ‘aClass[_Sub]’
[/quote]
what about anClass ?[/quote]
what about preschool grammar?

regardless, abraham, we’re not shoving the patterns down you’re throat… we’re shoving an elegant solution down your throat; feel free to modify the patterns. regardless, seeing as you’re stupid like me, you were completely oblivious to the RemappingClassAdapter and Remapper classes placed in org.objectweb.asm.util

Read full topic

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:328148”]pd wrote and released an open-source bytecode renamer that worked extremely well towards the end of the aryan days. I think he called it ‘factor’ and you can download it here:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/factor.tgz

As to whether updaters should rename, inject accessor methods, or anything else. I don’t really think they should do anything but output a map of fields to nice names. Then you can have as many programs as you want to parse that in and do whatever you want with it. But hey, to each their own I guess. :)[/quote]I took a look at the renaming subsection within the factor application and it is specific to ZKM’s deobfuscation renamer; he iterates through all the UTF8 constant pool entries and revises if they are to be replaced with the updated name checking to see if it matches with the following regex string:

.*?(a" + needle + "(?!_Sub|\\d)(?:(?:Array)*|_)+\\d+).*? which references object names like ‘aClass[_Sub]’

As I said before, taking his approach would have been much more facile, but I preferred to take the more generic approach seeing as my updater does not (and hopefully, will not) use ZKM’s deobfuscator beforehand, and I’d rather not have it rely on an external application.

pd wrote and released an open-source bytecode renamer that worked extremely well towards the end of the aryan days. I think he called it ‘factor’ and you can download it here:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/factor.tgz

As to whether updaters should rename, inject accessor methods, or anything else. I don’t really think they should do anything but output a map of fields to nice names. Then you can have as many programs as you want to parse that in and do whatever you want with it. But hey, to each their own I guess.

item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

abraham2119:

mines written in bcel because i cannot be fucked to learn objectweb’s asm api. i do not know much related to the api, but from what i have heard, it would be more frustrating to make a field-renamer in asm than in bcel due to the fact that asm limits you from direct modifications to constants in the constant pool

with regards to asm: thats not a bug its a feature.
The abstraction makes it much easier to use and much simpler to code for.
Have a look at their renaming classes though. In one of the recent versions they’ve built in classes specifically for this purpose.

abraham2119:

my current renaming solution is a bit slow (around 2-3 seconds on the whole client ), but i could not think of a better method at the time (without fucking with utf8 constants that do not pertain to the name/descriptor of a class member)

If it takes less than 5secs then its nothing to worry about.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Freddy1990, post:5, topic:328148”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=424530.msg3117749#msg3117749 date=1265190981]

instead of injecting hooks like most updaters do, it renames all identified fields in the client and updates all constant pool entries referencing the old names

Ah. Haven’t seen a renaming updater since the Aryan days. Problem is now that they send stack traces to the server on errors, it’s highly detectable. They also use more reflection now than they used to, making you more likely to be caught that way too.
[/quote]
I tried to write one with BCEL once, a bytecode refactorer, but I kinda failed back then, ASM would be more suited for the job…[/quote]mines written in bcel because i cannot be fucked to learn objectweb’s asm api. i do not know much related to the api, but from what i have heard, it would be more frustrating to make a field-renamer in asm than in bcel due to the fact that asm limits you from direct modifications to constants in the constant pool

my current renaming solution is a bit slow (around 2-3 seconds on the whole client ), but i could not think of a better method at the time (without fucking with utf8 constants that do not pertain to the name/descriptor of a class member)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:328148”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=424530.msg3117647#msg3117647 date=1265171323]
instead of injecting hooks like most updaters do, it renames all identified fields in the client and updates all constant pool entries referencing the old names
[/quote]

Ah. Haven’t seen a renaming updater since the Aryan days. Problem is now that they send stack traces to the server on errors, it’s highly detectable. They also use more reflection now than they used to, making you more likely to be caught that way too.[/quote]
I tried to write one with BCEL once, a bytecode refactorer, but I kinda failed back then, ASM would be more suited for the job…

item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Ah. Haven’t seen a renaming updater since the Aryan days. Problem is now that they send stack traces to the server on errors, it’s highly detectable. They also use more reflection now than they used to, making you more likely to be caught that way too.

If you want to take it apart and run it in a debugger (so you can hot replace code or otherwise) renaming is the only way to go. You could write a layer on top of reflection and stacktraces but given that a renaming bot would only be useful for dev it would simply be too much effort. Given the simplicity of a simple rename its easy to add to a deobber for shits and giggles.

Read full topic

instead of injecting hooks like most updaters do, it renames all identified fields in the client and updates all constant pool entries referencing the old names

Ah. Haven’t seen a renaming updater since the Aryan days. Problem is now that they send stack traces to the server on errors, it’s highly detectable. They also use more reflection now than they used to, making you more likely to be caught that way too.

item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

there havent been any updater outputs recently, so i figured id post the output of a new updater i was writing which i have not worked on in a while[code] - Downloading runescape.jar…

  • Loading classes…
  • Finished loading 518 classes from runescape.jar!
  • Loading identifiers…
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Login
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Applet
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Buffer
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Cipher
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Mouse
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.Node
    • Identifier loaded: com.abraham2119.rs.rename.id.PolylingualString
  • Finished loading 7 class identifiers!
  • Identifying classes and members…
  • Finished identifying all classes and members!
  • Renaming identified members…
    [ Login ]
    ^ Login = mm
    • Login.login(I)V = mm.e(I)V
      [ GameApplet ]
      ^ GameApplet = gv
    • GameApplet.error(Ljava/lang/String;Z)V = gv.a(Ljava/lang/String;Z)V
    • GameApplet.validHost(I)Z = gv.g(I)Z
      [ Buffer ]
      ^ Buffer = ae
    • Buffer.offset = ae.bb
    • Buffer.buff = ae.yb
      [ Cipher ]
      ^ Cipher = jv
      [ Mouse ]
      ^ Mouse = dk
    • Mouse.removeListeners(B)V = dk.e(B)V
    • Mouse.component = dk.U
    • Mouse.addListeners(ILjava/awt/Component;)V = dk.a(ILjava/awt/Component;)V
    • Mouse.posX = dk.P
    • Mouse.posY = dk.O
    • Mouse.storeEventAttr(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;B)V = dk.a(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;B)V
    • Mouse.reviseModifiers(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;I)I = dk.a(Ljava/awt/event/MouseEvent;I)I
      [ Node ]
      ^ Node = cg
    • Node.unlink(Z)V = cg.a(Z)V
      [ PolylingualString ]
      ^ PolylingualString = wt
    • PolylingualString.getString(II)Ljava/lang/String; = wt.a(II)Ljava/lang/String;
  • Finished renaming all identified members!
  • Dumping classes…
  • Finished dumping classes to runescape_out.jar!
    [/code]

instead of injecting hooks like most updaters do, it renames all identified fields in the client and updates all constant pool entries referencing the old names

Read full topic
